campaign.story:
In 2014, Magpie Games launched a Kickstarter for Urban Shadows, an ENnie award-winning tabletop roleplaying game of political urban fantasy that quickly became one of our flagship titles. For years, fans have praised both the game’s effortless explanation of the Powered by the Apocalypse engine and the groundbreaking content on race and urban communities, leading Urban Shadows to be a favorite of urban fantasy gamers, podcasters, and streamers alike.
Now—more than six years later—we are returning to the dark streets of the city for Urban Shadows: Second Edition, updating the game’s rules, look, and tools to better support moving stories of political urban fantasy. Featuring new playbooks, new faction mechanics, and completely revised materials from first edition, Urban Shadows 2E will thrust you into the danger and drama of the city like never before!
Urban Shadows is a political urban fantasy tabletop roleplaying game in which mortals and supernaturals alike vie for power in a modern-day city. Vampires, faeries, hunters, wizards, and more clash in the shadows...or make backroom deals for their piece of the streets and skyscrapers. No one is ever safe, and everything is always at stake.
In Urban Shadows, you play unique and powerful archetypes, protagonists who are attuned to the supernatural world. While the mortal world remains ignorant of the struggles of the city’s supernatural denizens, you are caught in the middle of the physical conflicts and political drama of the city’s past, present, and future.
You might be a spectre bound to an artifact, unable to move on until you’ve resolved your trauma. Or you might be a clever vampire who controls the best blood supply in the city, caught up in a war between your kind and those who hunt you. Or you might be a veteran of your city’s ancient conflicts, someone who got out of the game but keeps getting drawn back in by friends and allies.
No matter who you are, you contain within you the power to shape the city’s destiny. What future will you choose? And what will your victories cost you?
Urban Shadows is based on the Powered by the Apocalypse system used by tabletop RPGs like Apocalypse World, Dungeon World, and many of Magpie Games’s own titles such as Masks: A New Generation, Root: The RPG, and Zombie World. The game uses the core framework of that system to provide a strong, simple way to create your own stories of political urban fantasy. You’ll create a character using one of several archetypes, and then you’ll take action, rolling two six-sided dice to resolve the outcomes of dangerous and difficult situations.
Urban Shadows creates stories like those you’d find in Constantine, Diableros, The Dresden Files, The John Wick franchise, The Last Witchhunter, Lost Girl, and The Wire. 
In Urban Shadows, the city is a living, breathing character all its own. It hides dark desires, wicked deeds, and devious schemes, its shadowy tendrils a danger to mortals and supernaturals alike. Some residents have sacred sanctums or secure workshops—places to weather the storms of the city—but a sprawling metropolis lies just outside those little nooks, caring little if you prosper…or bleed out in the gutters.
But nobody faces the city alone. Even the humblest of imps has a small community, a circle of those who can offer solace in the face of problems and danger. But community is a double-edged sword—demanding as much as it gives—and the needs and desires of those same circles constantly shape and reshape the vibrant urban landscape of the city. Nothing lasts forever, but the city turns over nearly every night, different forces laying different claims to you and yours.
The city hungers. Will you sate its gnawing desires? Or will your enemies make you the feast?
The schemes and plots of supernatural beings have been a part of the city for as long as anyone can remember. The faces at the top may shift and change with the tides of fortune, but rarely does something occur in the mortal world without some push from those who lurk in the shadows. A new subway system? A contested election? A bank robbery? Nothing is what it seems.
But what is mere money or prestige to wizards, ghosts, and faeries? Who cares about cash or elections when trafficking in human souls or exploring other dimensions? The supernatural forces of the city—and the mortals who deal with them—know only one real currency: debt.
Debt is the power to influence those who owe you, the chits you call in to get things done, the ties that bind you to the rest of the city, and the proof that your word is strong and your bonds unbreakable. There are few true friends in the city, but your debtors always want to see you survive—you can’t pay up if you’re dead.
But there are other ways to triumph in the city beyond the economy of favors and patronage. Cruel rituals. Dark secrets. The temptations of the monster within you. Those who seek power at any cost will find no end to the magics and mysteries available for the merest price of a soul.
The streets bleed shadows—your debtors always around the corner—as the city threatens to swallow you whole. Will you die a hero… or live long enough to become the villain? Will you fight the darkness…or beg for power? The choice is yours.
Over the past five years, Magpie Games has developed and created multiple games that broke boundaries and redefined what PbtA can do. Now, we think it’s time to apply the lessons we’ve learned to Urban Shadows, making a game that’s tighter and easier to run, but also filled with new ideas and improvements, including new tools for players and GMs. We’re also excited to create a beautiful new book with visionary art and fantastic graphic design. In short… we’re making Urban Shadows 2E because we’re thrilled to revisit and refine our work!
Here’s a quick list of the major changes, many of which are already available in the quickstart:
revised basic moves, including new versions of turn to violence and let it out 
revised playbooks, including rebuilt versions of The Hunter and The Oracle 
two brand new playbooks: The Sworn (Power) and The Imp (Wild) 
changing Factions to Circles—see below—and adding Circle Status to represent standing
a new downtime phase of the game focused on player-facing city moves and rumors
replacing Storms with a new MC-facing faction turn, including new faction moves
expanded MC tools for generating your city and Circles at the start of play
We’re also adding a new mechanic to bring PCs into contact more often with each other: City Hubs. Cities are enormous spaces, and we found (in US1E) player characters could sometimes retreat to their different corners of the cityscape, interacting only with their own worlds and not with each other. With City Hubs, we want to create smaller, expandable environments to focus play and create drama. These Hubs—described below—position characters in neighborhoods, institutions, and community spaces in which they interact more frequently and avoid sessions in which PCs rarely come into contact and conflict.
Download the quickstart for a chance to test out some of these new features! We’ll be previewing more of them during the campaign, and we’re excited to get your feedback and refine Urban Shadows even more. Thank you to everyone who has given us feedback on 1st Edition since 2015!
 In Urban Shadows, your characters juggle relationships and obligations, seeking allies and opportunities, cashing in debts along the way to get things done. When you seize the day, you reshape the city in your image and unleash your powers on those who stand against you; when your enemies move and hunt, you do your best to stay ahead of the oncoming storm.
Urban Shadows uses the Powered by the Apocalypse framework to resolve interesting moments of uncertainty through moves, bits of mechanics that say: “When you do [x], [y] happens.” Each move trigger—the “When you do [x]” part—is designed to help point at moments of uncertainty, when neither the players nor the GM know exactly what happens next. Some examples of such moments include:
When you throw a punch at a loudmouthed werewolf in a demonic club
When you plead with the wizard’s council to return a tome of magic stolen from you
When you try to escape the evil ritual you stumbled onto in the city’s sewers
When you ask one of your companions to forgive the debt your fae lover owes them
When you trigger a move—when you perform the action described in the move’s trigger—then the rest of the move kicks into effect, often requiring a die roll. You roll 2d6 (two six-sided dice) and add in one of your stats to find out what happens.
Every playbook has four stats: 
 Blood is the measure of your fight or flight instincts. It tells us how tough, dangerous, coiled, and quick to act your character is in a perilous situation.
 Heart is the sum of your passion, charm, and charisma. It tells us how proficient your character is at getting what they want through negotiation and persuasion.
 Mind is a reflection of your critical thinking and analysis. It tells us how perceptive your character can be and how good they are at manipulating others through deceit.
 Spirit is a gauge of your connection to the “other” and your force of will. It tells us how focused your character is under pressure and what kind of power they can unleash.
Each stat is ranked from -3 to +3. You add your stat to some rolls when you trigger certain moves. For example, when you turn to violence, you roll 2d6 + Blood.
On most moves, if you get a 10 or higher (10+), things go your way! If you get a 7-9, you get what you were after, but usually with some cost or complication. If you get a 6 or lower, that’s called a miss, and the GM gets to tell you what happens next as things spiral out of control. 
Urban Shadows has basic moves for all the usual conflicts in urban fantasy—fighting, lying, escaping, magic, and more—along with special moves for managing debts and your relationships with communities at large.  
The city is a fierce cesspool of politics and corruption, but there are clear connections and boundaries between like-minded residents, spheres of influence that make up the scope of politics within the city. Most call these divisions Circles, loose political groupings that illustrate the differing affiliations and loyalties in the world, each one a community with its own internal politics and dramas. The Circles are:
In addition to the main stats, each character also has ratings (from -3 to +3) for their Circles, measures of how well the character understands each specific community. A character with a high rating in a Circle has contacts and connections within it, and can easily interpret its political information; a character with a low rating in a Circle doesn’t understand how that Circle works or who the power players are within that community.
Circles aren’t organizations or formal alliances; they are more like broad communities or subcultures. The disagreement between two members of the same Circle may be as—or more—intense than any conflict between two differing spheres. A werewolf and a vampire both hail from Night, but that doesn’t mean they get along. It only means they understand each other...and the violence inherent in the language of their streets.
Yet there are factions within each Circle capable of acting in unison, alliances who can shape the city’s future—werewolf packs, witch covens, faerie courts, and more. In Urban Shadows: Second Edition, we’re giving GMs new tools to support those factions in a “faction turn” between sessions. We’re also giving players new tools to get stuff done in downtime, acting on the rumors they heard about what the factions have done in the past week or two of offscreen activity, all fueling the drama of the city and the power players have to shape the setting.
Urban Shadows uses archetypes (The Wolf, The Wizard, The Oracle, etc.) to help players create characters quickly and easily. These archetypes are only ever a starting point; you can always bring in different myths, legends, and ideas to make your character entirely your own.
Characters often acquire abilities and powers from other archetypes and may even change archetypes over the course of play. As your character advances, you may also find reasons to retire to safety, securing that character’s place in the city as you create a new character to continue your group's story.  
Absolute power...corrupts absolutely. Urban Shadows features a dynamic corruption mechanic, tracking your character's descent into darkness. When you take a life, give in to your monstrous nature, or cross a line you shouldn't cross, you mark corruption. As you gain corruption, you unlock new and potent powers, allowing your character to get what they want—at the cost of further corruption. The dark side of your nature bears productive fruit.
Power is never free, though. Cross the line too often and you lose your character to the darkness, handing them over to the GM for them to play as a threat. Corruption is a downward spiral threatening to push you over the edge, and not everyone is cut out to make it back from the brink. As your character gains new abilities fueled by the growing darkness within, you face a difficult choice: will you give up what you've gained to save yourself? 
Corruption also encourages you to play to your archetype. Each archetype contains unique boundaries and taboos that define when you mark corruption. Life is always sacred, but werewolves, mages, and faeries all face unique temptations while stalking the city's streets.
Cities are giant, complex networks of interconnected communities caught in an almost constant state of change. In order to focus your characters’ conflicts and provide reasons for the players to consistently play together across those spaces, Urban Shadows 2E uses City Hubs—dynamic sections of urban life that frame the story you’re telling together without cutting you off from the rest of the city’s potential.
A City Hub isn’t just a physical district or area of your city. Instead, each Hub is a collection of institutions, relationships, and anchors—important NPCs—that create a background for the action in your story. Even better, Hubs can be added over the length of a campaign, expanding the city with new locations, conflicts, and NPCs as your story progresses. 
Urban Shadows 2E features four City Hubs, each dominated by one of the four Circles:
City Hall (Mortalis)
Downtown (Night)
The University (Power)
The Arts District (Wild)
Perhaps your Tainted is a student at the local university, the same campus that lies within the Wolf’s territory...and the same institution at which the Wizard recently started working as a professor. Or maybe your Oracle has an occult bookstore downtown in the same office building in which the Sworn is regularly summoned to meet with the wizard’s council, just down the street from the family restaurant in which the Aware still waits tables.
Hubs are also a flexible tool for structuring your campaign as a whole. You can use two different Hubs set in the same city for different campaigns, you can grab elements from any Hub to use as inspiration for your campaign, or you can expand your campaign to include new Hubs as your city grows. We’ll release new Hubs through this campaign as stretch goals and as digital supplements after the Kickstarter.
People have been playing Urban Shadows since 2013, and we love the stories they’ve told during that time. Check out what some of these fans and designers have to say about one of their favorite games:

We're happy to ship Urban Shadows 2E anywhere in the world!
We are charging shipping through Backerkit; your pledge does not include the cost of shipping. After the Kickstarter is over, we will use Backerkit to collect address information, handle add-ons and pre-orders, and charge you for shipping. The pledge manager will also allow backers to upgrade their pledge after the campaign is closed.
We expect basic shipping for the US2E Corebook to be roughly $10 US Domestic / $15 International Reshippers (CA/EU/UK/AU) / $20 Rest of World. Shipping for add-ons and physical stretch goals will raise the price for shipping an additional $5-$10, depending on the number and weight of the additional items. Our current plan is to ship everything—the core game, all add-ons, all stretch goals—in a single shipment.
All basic shipping is US/EU/CA/UK/AU-friendly. We will cover the cost of customs and VAT for those regions, and our reshippers will ensure that you receive the book from a local address within the region. Basic international shipping will not include tracking numbers, but our reshippers are quite fast at delivery!
If you are interested in upgrading to faster shipping or shipping that includes international tracking information through FedEx or DHL, you can indicate that you would like "Advanced Shipping" in our pledge manager. Upgraded shipping is likely to incur customs and VAT charges.
Retail shipping for this campaign is free. You will not be charged for shipping if you pledge at a retail tier, even if you are an international backer. Instead, we’ll cover the shipping as a thank you for supporting our work. We know operating a retail store is hard work even in the best of times, and we appreciate you all a ton!
All PDF products will be fulfilled through DriveThruRPG. We will deliver coupon codes for you to add Urban Shadows 2E to your library via Backerkit digital downloads.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
This is Magpie Games' twelfth Kickstarter, and we've got a long history of fulfilling projects, including Masks: A New Generation, Bluebeard's Bride, Zombie World, and many more for other folks (for example: 7th Sea: 2nd Ed). We've got a good grasp on how to get stuff designed, written, illustrated, shipped, and fulfilled.

The largest problem we've encountered is delays. We've taken all the steps we can to deliver this project on time, including devoting full-time staff members to preparing the design and writing. We'll keep backers informed at all times about what's happening with the project. Our commitment is always to the quality of our work, but nothing makes us happier than shipping games!
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

campaign.story:
Kickstarted in 2018 and released globally in 2019, Black Void is an acclaimed dark esoteric tabletop role-playing game.
The Black Void RPG revolves around the fall and subsequent resurgence of Humanity after cataclysmic events have torn them from Earth. Pursuing power, prestige, and enlightenment - humanity is struggling to find a new place and purpose in a vast and unfamiliar cosmos. Players can focus on the personal struggles and stories of their characters or expand their scope putting emphasis on the fate of humanity as a species and the part they play in this.
The princely envoy leans over the gently swaying railing of the massive vessel, his gaze taking in the bustling Dhaarese docks hazily bathed in the dwindling light of the setting second sun of Llyhn.
A faint sense of contempt and annoyance emanates from his posture as his eyes swerve towards the opposite shore and distant Khameeliyah district. The ruined tower, barely visible among the palaces and villas, is a stark reminder of the envoy’s last visit to the city of the Unseen Rulers.
Suddenly distracted from its musings by a putrid stink oozing from the nearby island district - known locally as Kimah - the majestic figure lifts an intricately woven and embroidered shawl to cover its delicate features as it turns toward the waiting Je’ehl posse. “Find them or risk your master’s ire!”
The envoy’s gaze turns back to Dhaarese as the Je’ehl leap into the waiting dinghies. “It’s time to hunt humans again” shouts the leader, securing her three-bladed dagger to her hip, “…and remember, we need them alive!”
"Black Void: Under Nebulous Skies" is the eagerly-anticipated sourcebook and campaign for the Black Void role-playing game. 
Packed with new setting material, new character options including playable halfblood selections, and the first part of the grand campaign trilogy; this book is a must-have for Black Void fans.
The book's 250+ pages will have abundant beautiful art, detailing new creatures, sentient species, maps, a deep-dive into the Kimah and Dhaarese districts, intriguing NPC's and much, much more.
Divided into three main sections, this book has something for everyone! An exciting player's options section, a comprehensive travelogue and the first part of the Grand Campaign Trilogy, that will be continued in future volumes.

Crammed with new options for character creation, the Players option is a treasure trove for players and Arbiters alike.
Several new Talents, Skills and Attributes give players a wider selection for character individualisation than ever before. While new halfblood background options such as Talath-kin and Je'ehl-kin now enable players to access and connect with some of the predominant species of the Eternal City.

The new Attributes allow players to make their characters even more otherworldly and exotic than before, with such options as Symbiotic bond or detachable limbs.
Various novel Esoteric Attributes such as translucence allow players and Arbiters to create truly alien characters and NPC's to populate their adventures.
Ten new exotic weapons, such as the Suwayyah dagger, make combat even more interesting (and deadly) than ever before.
New Combat specialisations give battle-oriented characters a more comprehensive range of possibilities to employ than ever before.
A deeper look into travelling the Void, as well as the vessels and crews, give Arbiters and players further possibilities for exploring the worlds beyond Llyhn. 
A comprehensive list of Void vessels, crew options, and vessel upgrades enables players and Arbiters to build their own Void vessels for expeditions into the oblivious depths.
This section is an in-depth guide, detailing two of the most exhilarating districts of Llyhn the Eternal: Kimah and Dhaarese.
Immerse yourself in the perilous underworld of the Kimah district, where thugs and goons hang on every corner, doom-spouting prophets vie for your soul and beggars grasp for your purse. Visit a multitude of enticing and unnerving hidden dives, where shady patrons know secrets best kept in the dark. And peruse the plazas and obscure shops peddling junk, contraband, and filched goods, with the occasional hidden treasure amongst the rubbish.
The Dhaarese district is – in the eyes of some – the life-nerve of the Eternal City. It is here that the bulk of the massive Red Galleys and other prominent Void vessels put into port. Ships from across the known Cosmos unload their cargoes of rare and exotic substances, objects, and artefacts from faraway worlds while the otherworldly crew bring tales of distant lands, wonders and horrors.
The chapter provides a comprehensive look into locations such as the Feeradani enclave, The midnight market, Beggars Court, the Wharves, and many other places. While notable personages, prevalent factions, maps, building layouts provide everything you need to bring the meanest districts of Llyhn to life.
“The distant thunder is barely audible over the pouring rain as you move to stand solemnly amongst the gathered mourners. A simple litter holding the shrouded body rests nearby next to a shallow hole and a heap of piled mud and clay. The downpour has soaked the linen covering the body, showing her sunken features, and smearing the funerary cosmetics unto the cloth, giving it the eerie semblance of a skull.”
- Introduction to "Under Nebulous Skies: Scene 1".
"Under Nebulous Skies" is the first part of a Grand campaign trilogy, continued in future releases. The campaign is intended for newly created characters with an engaging storyline taking the protagonists on a harrowing and wondrous journey into the depths of Llyhn, and beyond the Eternal City. 
True to form, this Black Void adventure allows players to employ their diplomacy, stealth, combat skills, social proclivities, powers, and any other desperate means as they seek to unravel the mystery thrust upon them and confront the horrors and cruelty lurking under the surface of Llyhn and in the Cosmos at large.
The characters can explore multiple locations in Kimah and Dhaarese, interacting with a vast and colourful NPC gallery as the story takes them deep into Llyhn, and later to a Ka’Alum federation world and beyond as they seek to uncover the ominous aspirations of a shadowy perpetrator with its gaze set firmly on the descendants of Earth.
The global logistics and trade situation is fluctuating and it is difficult to predict shipping costs for when we begin fulfilment in 2021. However, we are committed to getting the physical books as cheaply and efficiently into your hands as possible and are partnering with a trusted logistical company to do so.
Shipping will be charged in the Pledge Manager after the campaign is over based on your pledge and selected physical add-ons (if any).
The below are estimated regional shipping costs based on current rates for a single Black Void: Under Nebulous Skies (hardback) copy.
EU ≈ $16  |  UK ≈ $13  |  US ≈ $20  |  RoW ≈ $20+
If you are intrigued but want to know more before diving in, you can download the FREE Quickstart and accompanying adventure.
If you want to grab the Core Rulebook or another Black Void product while you are at it, there is a 15% DISCOUNT on all Black Void adventures, screens, dice, and so on for the entirety of the Kickstarter campaign on the MODIPHIUS WEB SHOP and DRIVETHRURPG.COM
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Black Void: Under Nebulous Skies is currently 60% written and edited, with significant amounts of artwork either done or WIP. We expect the PDF versions of the book to be sent out in April 2021, with the physical copies following a few months after depending on production time.

However, as with all creative projects, delays may occur due to artwork issues, software or print problems and so on. Please know that we are committed to getting the book to you as fast as we possibly can without skimping on the quality. We trust that you - like us - would rather want this book one week later and in top quality, than one week earlier with errors that could have been avoided.

This is the second kickstarter campaign for the team and we are very excited about launching another project. We pledge to be transparent, keeping you up-to-date on our progress and letting you know as quickly as possible, should any mishaps or delays occur.

Thank you very much for your trust and support!
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

A collection never before seen...
Join a team of award-winning Trophy Dark incursion writers as you explore terrible places and uncover wondrous formulas for transformation with this collection of nine all-new, fully-illustrated adventures in one luxurious hard-bound volume. 
artwork by Madeleine Ember
What is Trophy Dark?  
 Trophy Dark is a collaborative storytelling game by Jesse Ross about a group of treasure-hunters on a doomed expedition into a forest (or other space) that doesn’t want them there. As they get closer and closer to the location's heart, it does everything it can to tear them apart, drive them mad, and—if they’re lucky—kill them. It's a fantastic one-shot game which has seen great success through its recent Kickstarter and vibrant community of players and writers. Trophy Dark  creates a deeply atmospheric story through its narrative, theme-oriented structure and collaborative format.
What is Alchemy? 
Alchemy will be an offset-printed, smythe-sewn, casebound book containing 9 brand-new incursions for Trophy Dark. Each never-before-seen scenario will allow you and your friends to take on the roles of desperate adventurers, pressing their luck in search of treasure and ultimately meeting their doom! The rules for Trophy Dark  will be included in Alchemy, so you do not need any other materials to play.
Cover concept (design not final)
The Incursions
AL-IKSIR by Nicholas Masyk - Every 1,001 nights, the decaying lich-lords of the blighted city of Shi'Hadith descend from their hideous ziggurats to claim the AL-IKSIR, a bubbling cauldron of distilled souls brewed by faceless servitors in the festering heart of the ancient city. Only through the AL-IKSIR can they maintain their un-life for a further 1,001 nights. Only through grudging cooperation can they slither beneath the watchful eyes of those citizen-sorcerers who seek to claim lichdom for themselves. But there is scarcely enough AL-IKSIR to sustain even a single lich, and so only the most cunning might attain the ultimate goal of immortal life...
BLACK STAR BOLT by Speak the Sky - DEATH RACE ON A DEAD PLANET UNDER FURIOUS STAR SPEWING DARKNESS. ORGY OF VEHICULAR VIOLENCE. WHAT GORGEOUS ALCHEMY MAKES FIRE AND LIGHTNING OF CRUDE & SAINTS AND HEROES OF KILLERS? DON'T ANSWER THAT LET'S DIE NOW! TOTAL CATASTROPHONY!
City of Gold by Amalie McKee - People you thought lost to the desert have been returning to your town of ne'er-do-wells with ears of gold and stories of angels. If you can retrace their steps and meet these angels yourself, you could return to society a wealthy hero, though you might sacrifice your humanity along the way.
DIE, GRAVE ROBBER, DIE! by Michael Van Vleet - Resurrectionists have wrenched a corpse from out of the sacred soil where it was to find eternal rest. Crawl through rat-filled tunnels, wander among horrifying medical exhibits and storm the Flayed House of Dr. Galfani to get a mourning family their beloved relation back!
Lovelorn Lamentations by Pam Punzalan - The misery, rage, and mourning over love unrequited transformed a once cursed Princess into a feathered Lady of Tears. They say she was killed by the other gods already, and that the empty halls of her palatial home hold wonders that surpass human comprehension. Yet, all who have entered the place don't emerge the same, if they even emerge at all.
illustration by RAPIDPUNCHES
Susurrae by Madeleine Ember - Peel back the layers of self along this strange journey into the ruined St. Rheis Monastery, below it to the crypt-rot catacombs, and finally to the caverns of sight beyond seeing. What the treasure-hunters seek is truth - answers to the questions that will otherwise destroy them. Learning the truth can be dangerous.
The Dark Ascent by Natalie Ash - One day a year, the entrance to Mount Rames and the Path of Ascent is open. Within its halls, you and your fellow aspirants can gain ultimate power! But at what price?
Incursions will feature fantastic illustrations (like this one from RAPIDPUNCHES)
The Queen of Swords, A Crown of Blades by Jamila R. Nedjadi - After assassinating the queen, you are on the run bearing secrets and gold - can you survive the vengeful spirit that stalks you?
Renewal by Gabriel Robinson - Deep in a mist-shrouded forest, secret medicines of the Ancients promise miraculous powers to worthy aspirants—or so the enigmatic Guide tells you. Leave the trappings of your worldly life behind, embrace your true calling and be reborn... 
Stretch goals
Stretch Goals for this project are focused on two things: making the book an even more luxurious masterpiece and increasing our ability to solicit art and support contributors.
At $16,000, we'll be upgrading the cover to include foil stamping and debossing.
At $20,000, we can expand guest contributions & artwork.
At $25,000, we'll add a ribbon bookmark.
Timelines
Our goal is to put a PDF of five of the incursions in your hand by the end of October - ready for your Halloween horror games. The complete PDF should be in your hands by the end of the year, and the print version should begin shipping in February. 
Shipping
Given the ongoing changes related to the postal systems of the world, we will not be charging shipping as part of the campaign. We will collect shipping charges through a pledge manager when we prepare for fulfillment.
Contributors
AMALIE MCKEE 
Amalie "Mags Maenad" McKee (they/them, @MaenadMags) is the desert-dwelling author of Climbing the Witch’s Tower, a tarot-inspired Rooted in Trophy project, and a prolific GM. 
GABRIEL ROBINSON 
Gabriel Robinson (he/him, @trollhands) is the creator of Candlelight, a Rooted in Trophy game of restless spirits seeking hope. He is also a contributor to Sunken and the Trophy RPG (Trophy Dark, Gold, and Loom) including the award-winning incursions Gift of the Sea and Leviathan’s Bridge (Trophy Gold contest winner 2020).
JAMILA R. NEDJADI
Jamila R. Nedjadi (they/them, @temporalhiccup) is the creative force behind Sword Queen Games. They make games to inspire intuitive creativity and invoke catharsis. Jammi has made many sacrifices to the forest and has received its crown of glass and blood with honor. May the forest always be fed, may the crown grant visions of gold and clarity.
MADELEINE EMBER 
Madeleine Ember (she/her, @MadeleineEmber) is the writer and illustrator of the Troika! Zine So You’ve Been Thrown Down A Well, the Trophy Dark incursion Shiver, and is co-creator of the Richter campaign setting. Her writings and illustrations can be found in a variety of products including Candlelight, Sunken, Xenophon, Under the Floorboards, Dissident Whispers, and all three official Trophy RPG books: Trophy Dark, Trophy Gold, and Trophy Loom.
MICHAEL VAN VLEET 
Michael Van Vleet (he/him, @signalstation) is the author of several Trophy Dark incursions, including the award-winning A Warm and Pleasant Hum (which you may already own as part of the Bundle for Racial Justice and Equality on itch.io) and Devil, Aim For Me, a Weird West incursion. He's also a contributor to the official Trophy Gold and Trophy Loom projects, coming in 2021.
NATALIE ASH 
 Natalie Ash (she/her, @TheNatalieAsh) is a game designer, writer, and layout artist. Her recent credits include work in Voidheart Symphony, Candlelight, Sunken, Dissident Whispers, Outrageous Owlbears, and contributed several works to the forthcoming Trophy Gold. She is the co-creator of the Richter campaign setting, writer of the award-winning Trophy Dark incursion The Huntsman’s Feast, and writer of the highly-rated Trophy Dark incursion Project Galileo which she is re-working into a dark sci-fi TTRPG called Isolation. 
NICHOLAS MASYK
Nicholas Masyk (he/him, @nicholasmasyk) is a biracial Black Canadian roleplaying game designer, editor, GM and layout artist from Montreal, Quebec, and creator of Monkey's Paw Games. Through such projects as UNCONQUERED: The Million-Million Spheres, Chalice, and MIGHTY THEWS, his games seek to inject anti-colonial, anti-racist, and anti-fascist narratives into the lens of science fiction, pulp fantasy, and horror. In addition to his own works, Nicholas has written for The Gauntlet's Codex, Trophy: Dark, Candlelight, Mnemonic: A Weaver’s Almanac, The Strategic Review, There's Something in the Ice, and Disk Horse#1: Off to the Races.
PAM PUNZALAN
Pam Punzalan, aka Pammu, (she/they, @TheDovetailor) is a queer designer, editor, sensitivity consultant and #RPGSEA community point person based in Manila. She's been published under Shadow Operations for Spire, and is involved in multiple projects big and small. Her biggest personal release is Sundo: We, Once Mortal, a PtbA game about psychopomps rebelling against a world that has lied to them about the truth of their nature.
SPEAK THE SKY
Speak the Sky (they/them, @SpeaktheSky) is a queer designer and writer making artefact games of the heart's cartography! They got their start in Trophy Dark with the acclaimed incursion The Paperflesh Advent, soon to be joined by spiritual sequel The Impostrous Emissariat, and recently hosted the Trophy Trifolds jam on http://itch.io. Their work outside of Trophy includes: Twilight Song, the pastoral sci-fi map-and-story game; Dirty Papers, the 200-word RPG Challenge finalist about archaeology and power; and Like Skyscrapers Blotting Out The Sun, the duet writing game of deep footnotes and woes in translation.
Cold Hearth Collective
Cold Hearth Collective is Amalie Mckee, Madeleine Ember, Natalie Ash, Michael Van Vleet and Gabriel Robinson. As a group of independent creators and publishers, we produce tabletop role-playing and fiction content with a focus on dark fantasy and horror. By pooling our skills and resources we provide a centralized network for print distribution, peer feedback and promotion, and collaborative opportunities for our contributors.
Cold Hearth Collective seeks to amplify diverse viewpoints and new voices through supporting, hiring, and publishing. We stand against bigotry in all forms including racism, sexism, queerphobia or other forms of harm towards marginalized groups.
Follow us on Twitter @ColdHearthClctv ! 
We print with PrintNinja

updates.update_content:
Hello, wonderful backers!
We have continued to scratch our heads and stare in bewilderment at international shipping. We want everyone, globally, to be able to enjoy a physical copy of our horrifying goods, but it seems difficult to do that affordably. International shipping promises to cost anywhere from $27 to $100. The most feasible option is using a USPS flat rate padded envelope, which would run around $27 to countries where USPS can deliver. Unfortunately, due to COVID-19 border closures, that is many fewer than usual. We will continue to look for options, and would certainly appreciate any suggestions from you.

Wow! Thanks so much to all of you for supporting our horror-filled and ambitious project! We're excited to share with you the amazing incursions our contributors are writing!
If you've backed, there's a good chance you know what Trophy Dark is, but in case you don't: It's a rules-light RPG game of fantasy-horror that requires standard 6-sided dice and imagination. The game is play-to-lose, so every player creates a character with a name, a few skills, a driving goal, and a single stat (Ruin) that charts their downfall. Over the course of a game, the players will collaborate and tell the best possible story of how their characters meet their doom. If you're new to RPGs or are introducing RPGs to someone who likes horror, it's a great place to start.

campaign.story:
Salt is a complete, challenging  full color 34 page Sci-Fi Horror adventure module compatible with the ENnie award winning Mothership Sci-Fi Horror RPG by Tuesday Knight Games.
The story begins as the player’s ship is damaged/sabotaged and is forced to land on a nearby ocean based planet. There is a brief moment of joy for the crew as they find themselves in a paradise-like, tranquil setting. The peace does not last long as the  ocean unleashes a devastating Tsunami. The race is on...
The crew has to gain access to an unmarked research facility, make their way through the compound while solving the mystery of what happened to the researchers, escaping from several terrifying creatures, enemy NPCs, all while trying to avoid drowning in the flooding base.
The key to any suspenseful horror game is the ever decreasing odds of survival. Do your players have what it takes to survive?
SALT is a full color 34 page Sci-Fi Horror survival module (8"x10"). Little prep time is needed to run this fast paced one-shot module. Perfect for first time or experienced Wardens. 
- Easy to follow layout, includes full room descriptions, provides descriptive text to read, warden information and tips for every room.
- Handouts that are given to specific players to create additional tension between players and promote dynamic role playing
- Three brand new horrific creatures
- A non-creature threat that is just as deadly and adds a time element to the game.
- Seven NPCs to interact with. Each with stats, backgrounds and motives.
- A map of the unregistered research facility.
- Thirteen new weapons. A lot of Sci-Fi horror games rely on avoiding the threat, but when it does come time to fight.. you might as well have the high-tech upper hand.
- A reference section with creature, weapon and NPC stats.
- Additional hooks for once the adventure is completed.
This adventure has many challenges for the players to overcome: A race against the clock, several terrifying creatures, enemy NPCs, puzzles, mysteries, internal conflict… and the biggest challenge is the fear of not surviving.
Mothership is a sci-fi horror roleplaying game that places a huge emphasis on being easy to run but difficult to beat. It uses a simple d100 roll-undersystem similar to Call of Cthulhu. It is incredibly easy to hack to meet your table's needs (increasing and decreasing the difficulty as necessary to create a fun and challenging time. More info here.
Yes. Although I suggest Mothership, with a few tweaks of the stats and the inclusion of stress roles, this module can easily be used with any space RPG: Traveler, Stars Without Numbers, Starfinder, Eclipse Phase, Savage Worlds, and even Star Wars.

campaign.story:
Join Our Discord Server! We're nice. 
Arium is the name of our game! Why? Well, because we wanted a simple name that expressed the idea of a container for possibility. There are all kinds of ariums in our daily lives: aquariums, solariums, planetariums-- we looked up the Latin root, and it felt perfect!
We like to think of it like this: an Arium is an overarching world, universe, setting, and story/adventure seeds. It contains a collection of fascinating landmarks, people, and items too!
Arium is our answer to a simple question: why play in someone else's sandbox when the whole group can have a blast creating their own?
The Arium roleplaying game system is delivered in two full-color books (PDF or print + PDF). 
Both Arium books will be available in print and PDF formats (mockup). Cover art by Andreas Rocha.
Arium: Create contains our refreshing and intuitive system for creating your own Arium, and you'll do it in one or two hours! The Arium you create will be unique to your group, and we promise everyone will be in love with it.  Create encourages folks to err on the side of awesome when collaborating to build their Arium, and the result is often surprising, but never disappointing! With a little work, you can take your resulting Arium and use it with any game system, or we've built in a seamless transition to our roleplaying rules found in Arium: Discover. 
Interior Arium: Create Art by Tithi Luadthong
Arium: Discover will work with any world. Take your favorite TV series,  your homebrew setting, or a movie/novel and quickly adapt to run it with Discover. Even better, build an Arium together using Arium: Create as a basis for your game. Arium: Discover builds on your universe by letting players take ownership of characters, items, and locations. Then, it's off to tell the story! Adventure, horror, and comedy are all on the table. Sci-fi, fantasy, and intrigue also possibilities! The streamlined d6-based system will feel familiar yet flexible. Additionally, the system of Boons and Banes encourages play that explores the important and meaningful by focusing on the relevant thematic elements of your Arium.  
Interior Arium: Discover Art by Tithi Luadthong
The funds generated by this campaign will fund the printing of both Arium books. Any additional raised funds will allow us to create further products via stretch goals to enhance the Arium experience.
Arium: Create is complete and set for printing and digital distribution. Backers will receive their PDF copy the day we receive funds from Kickstarter. Discover is ready for editing and layout. Based on the length of the process preparing Create for printing and distribution, we suspect this will take a couple of months. As soon as both books are ready, we will submit the files to the printer and order shipping materials.
The physical books are digest-size saddle-stitched zines (5.5" x 8.5"). Arium: Create is 48 full-color pages, and Arium: Discover is approximately full-color 48 pages. We're printing them through Mixam using high-quality materials and finishes. Backers get all of this content, assuming we fund, and we have stretch goals in place that will add even more helpful tools to Arium.
Either way, backers will receive both Create and Discover in PDF only for $8 or in print + PDF for $20!  
Interior Arium: Discover Art by Tithi Luadthong
The Digital Arium
For those who prefer all digital, we've got you! Our digital tier includes both Arium: Create and Arium: Discover, so your group has everything they need to create your Arium and play in it. Backers will receive PDF copies of both books, as well as Arium reference materials and character/Arium sheets you can print out for the table or use on a laptop or tablet. Includes:
Arium: Create PDF
Arium: Create Quick Reference PDF
Arium: Create Results Sheet PDF
Arium: Discover PDF
Arium: Discover Quick Reference PDF
Arium: Discover Character Sheet PDF
The Physical Arium
If you collect paper rectangles or prefer to have a physical copy at your table while playing, we have a treat for you! We're printing Arium: Create and Arium: Discover in two high-quality saddle-stitched zines using Mixam (a US-based printer who uses all reusable materials and recycles everything they don't use). We're printing in full color on satin-finished paper with a soft-touch cover on high-density paper. These books will shine in your collection! Includes:
Printed Arium: Create 5.5" x 8.5" Saddle-Stitched Book
Printed Arium: Discover 5.5" x 8.5" Saddle Stitched Book
Arium: Create PDF
Arium: Create Quick Reference PDF
Arium: Create Results Sheet PDF
Arium: Discover PDF
Arium: Discover Quick Reference PDF
Arium: Discover Character Sheet PDF
"Arium: Create is a system where everyone at the gaming table has a vested interest in the setting they are creating. I found it easy to learn and use [and] I'm excited to put Arium: Create into greater use as I introduce the complete process to my gaming group." -Daniel Yocom Guild Master Gaming
"Arium: Create strikes me as a very good tool [...] I’d say that even if I were to run a game in an established setting there are elements here that could be used in a session zero to establish some baselines and really explore what my group of players 'want’ from a game. Indeed, I even think that some groups may find enjoyment from simply taking a session to use Arium: Create for nothing other than to let their imagination take hold." -Adam Brown Big Comic Page
Arium: Create is all about creating a world your entire group will love using a series of seven steps: Lacunae, Universal, Big Picture, Culture & Organizations, Landmarks, People, and Goodies. These are the essential elements of your Arium.
During each step, the group works through three phases:
1. First, they generate ideas. Fast! With a timer. Timing the ideating ensures the ideas aren't TOO perfect, and it keeps the session flowing along.
2. During the second phase, the group reviews the ideas and combines them for one of two reasons. The first is when the concepts are samey, and the second, when a combination is fantastic and the creators agree their ideas should live or die together in the name of awesome.
3. In the third and final phase, the group brings democracy to bear and votes for their favorite ideas. In this way, the best ideas remain a part of the Arium, AND they live on to be guiding concepts for the following steps! 
What happens if your favorite idea didn't make the cut? No problem! Each player receives three creation tokens they can use to make sure their chosen concept becomes part of the final Arium.
Finally, we have rules for resolving player selection of People, Goodies, and even Locations to be theirs when the group moves on to roleplay in their fresh new Arium!
"I first played the RPG gem Arium: Create in its early stages, prior to its current state of elegance, and I've never laughed so hard nor felt so deeply for a new game. I had goosebumps - and that was before we went on to play the brilliant Discover. This is world-building and world-roaming genius."  -R. Jon Rock, tabletop gamer, author, RPG & short fiction editor, mental health nurse, professor, pretty good dude.
Arium: Create is complete and ready for digital delivery and printing.
See Arium: Create in action:
Arium: Discover is our D6-based roleplay rules that will feel familiar and play fast for streamlined gaming while enabling your group to explore the unique Arium they've created. In our skillless system, characters have four primary attributes: Mind, Body, Spirit, and Heart. The six secondary attributes are all derived from the primaries. They are Offense, Defense, Social, Willpower, Awareness, and Stamina.
The final and most crucial part of character creation is the process of assigning powerful Boons and Banes that bring your character to life and give them depth.
Last, it wouldn't be Arium if we didn't have a little something up our sleeves to help players progress and effect the Arium around them. Everyone receives Discovery Tokens that enable them to add to the Arium and help the group along the way.
Arium: Discover is in final revisions before heading off to editing and layout. We expect to be ready to print by the end of 2020.

We do have stretch goals planned if we fund! Here's the great news about them: All backers at The Digital Arium pledge level and above get every stretch goal we reach. So please help us spread the word about Arium, and everyone wins! 
 Arium: Flash, will be a guide to adapting an Arium to different types of plots for quick game sessions. Our talented stretch goal authors will each provide five story seeds within a theme or genre that you can use to jumpstart your story. At this level, we will add two new special guest authors: Jessica Marcrum and Jason H. Abbott. They will be contributing story seeds that evoke cute fantasy/horror and gonzo themes (respectively)!
Arium: Flash will be a free digital reward for all Digital Arium and higher backers.
Arium: Flash, will now include story seeds from two new special guest authors: Emmett Nahil and Kristen Devine. Emmett's themes will be post-apocalyptic, and Kristen's will be a mix of fantasy/sci-fi!
Arium: Flash will now include story seeds from two new special guest authors: Marlon Moss and Steffie de Vaan. Marlon is going to help us with modular plots for hard-boiled neo-noir Ariums, and Steffie will help groups who want to creep into gothic horror!
Arium: Bridge will be a guide to adapting an Arium to use with other RPG systems. Alan Bahr will create Bridges to 5e, Fate, and TinyD6.
Arium: Bridge will be a free digital reward for all Digital Arium and higher backers.
Arium: Flash will now include story seeds from two new special guest authors: Cat Evans and Mario Ortegón. Cat will bring us high fantasy plots, and Mario is going to deliver sci-fi with a neat twist!
Arium: Flash will now include story seeds from THREE new special guest authors: Chris Bissette, Lynne M. Meyer, and Katie Young. Chris comes to us with inspiration for stories of fae-folklore, Lynne is tackling swashbuckling themes, and Katie will work the western angle!
Arium: Flash will now include story seeds from two new special guest authors: Doug Levandowski and Arietta. Doug is going to give us an absurdist bent on victorian gothic, and Arietta is going to deliver a key element for some games, romance! 
Arium: Flash will now include story seeds from two new special guest authors: Pam Punzalan and Mitchell Wallace. We're hoping Pam will sneak in some spy/ops themes, and Mitchell will apply his wit to dark humor with a touch of horror!

campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
The greatest risk is printing and shipping zines, we’ve never done this before, but we're using Mixam, a high-quality printing shop and our book designer is a pro. We're fairly confident everything will go well. If all else fails, we could print the zines ourselves on a color laser printer and fold and staple them like the zine creators of old.

It’s possible we’ll miss our dates, but the Create PDF is complete. You'll get that right away. Discover needs a little more editing and layout, but it is our number one focus. Stretch goal timelines are those most at-risk to slip.

While this is Adept Icarus's first Kickstarter campaign, we've been students of crowdfunding for years. Additionally, Will was a co-producer on the Gallant Knight Games project, Zorro: The Roleplaying Game, and has learned a lot from the experience.

We've taken extra precaution to keep our pledge levels simple and not get in above our capabilities, but in the event that something does go wrong, we will adapt and find a way to deliver nonetheless. We've also Identified backups for the key roles, so rest assured, we have the folks we need to deliver Arium as promised!

campaign.story:
All stretch goals unlocked, including foil stamped zine covers!
You are the last surviving crew member of the intergalactic salvage ship The Wretched. Adrift between stars after an engine failure, your ship was attacked by a hostile alien lifeform. The crew are dead.
You thought you had won. You launched the creature out of an airlock, and that should have meant safety.
It didn’t.
The Wretched
The Wretched is a solo journaling/roleplaying game played with a deck of cards, a tumbling block tower, and a microphone.
The Wretched is a game about human resilience in the face of overwhelming odds and almost certain death. It is a game about isolation, fear, and perseverance.
You play a lone survivor of an horrific attack. You have seen and done terrible things, you have seen your friends - your found family - brutally butchered by something you can’t even begin to comprehend, something that you were sure didn’t exist until it manifested itself aboard your ship.
You are existing on the edges of your endurance, high on adrenaline and fear and desperation. You are sure you won’t survive this, but all you know to do is to keep fighting.
The Wretched is inspired by the music of John Carpenter and Nine Inch Nails, as well as You Are Not Alone In This Life and you will die alone out here in the black by Auden Roswell.
The Zine
The game was originally released in April 2020 with an initial print run of 25 that sold out almost immediately. Since then I've received multiple requests to reprint it, and now I'm turning to Kickstarter to make that happen.
The Wretched will be printed on 130 gsm silk paper with a sturdy 250 gsm recycled paper cover. This new print run has a new wraparound cover, an updated layout, and some quality-of-life updates to the text (including a new section covering safety tools). Printing will be handled by Mixam UK.
Mockup of the new zine. The new layout and cover are finalised.
Mockup of the zine showing the new layout.
These are mockups of the new zine. The new layout and cover are finalised - all this campaign will be funding is the print run! 
Stretch Goals
You want stretch goals? We've got stretch goals!
Goal number 1 is unlocked and I'll be writing more music for the soundtrack - including an exclusive track just for Kickstarter backers.
Goal number 2 is unlocked and you can now order the Wretched logo on t-shirts!
Goal number 3 is unlocked and I'll be writing even more music and pressing it on vinyl. These extra tracks will be exclusive to backers.
Goal number 4 gets a foil stamped cover. Mixam requires a minimum order of 1000 copies for this, so I'm setting a stretch goal of 800 backers at a physical zine level to make this happen!
I'm using Monster Press in the UK to print the t-shirts. I've worked with them several times in the past to produce my band's merch and know their quality and processes. Shirts will be a single colour print on Gildan Heavy.
Digital mock-up of the soundtrack vinyl. Final appearance subject to change.
 The Kickstarter-exclusive soundtrack will be pressed on a 110g 10" disc with printed labels and a 10" 300gsm printed outer sleeve. Manufacturing will be handled by DMS, a UK-based manufacturer and supplier of vinyl records with an excellent track record of producing quality work.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
All the writing is already done (the game was released in April along with the soundtrack). The new layout and cover have been finished already, and I've priced everything up with Mixam. Since ZineQuest in February I've printed 6 games with Mixam and fulfilled them all myself, so my process with both the printer and shipping out zines is fairly well-oiled at this point.

Obviously unforeseen events could still occur. Last time I ran a Kickstarter, COVID happened right as the campaign ended. But most risk should be minimised here - all I need to do once Kickstarter deposits the money is send out the digital files, upload the zine to Mixam, and get them shipped out to you! Even though this should be very quick, I've given an estimate of December for fulfillment. This is to account for any issues and also any delays introduced by us hitting stretch goals.

campaign.story:
ORBITAL gives us airlocks and control panels, pensive faces looking out into the cosmos, improvised fixes for critical systems, military-sponsored subterfuge, warm embraces in the cold vacuum, frantic struggles in zero-gravity and unknowable ancient technology, asking WHAT DO YOU DO NEXT?
Cover art for ORBITAL, by turbo.torbo
Imagine an all-consuming interstellar war, spread across a vast galaxy and involving trillions of willing and conscripted participants. Then imagine a lone space station, floating in the cosmos, that is somehow set apart from this conflict.
Through significant effort and fortuitous circumstance this place has remained unaffiliated and relatively peaceful, providing a sanctuary for the lovers and thinkers who refuse to side with the two warring powers.
But this hard-won neutrality is not secure, not even slightly. There’s always someone offering vital resources in exchange for a little influence, or plotting to displace our leaders, or smuggling military equipment into forgotten corners of the station.
Holding off these myriad threats is an informal network of dependable sorts, each with a stake in the continuing vitality of the station. These characters; politicos, artisans, brokers and so on, may not be officially recognised leaders—but their influence is felt strongly across the community.
They might not get along — they might not even like each other. But they are united by their belief that the station is a cherished place that must be protected. The question is: when the pressure is rising, can they put their differences & personal motivations aside for the good of the community?
Orbital
So, how does ORBITAL actually play?
ORBITAL employs the No Dice, No Masters system, utilising the core structure & mechanics from the wonderful Dream Askew by Avery Alder. This means two main things:
 There are no dice —players use tokens when they want their characters to take action, making 'moves'. Strong moves, which show the character at their best, require a token to be spent. Weak moves, which show the character's flaws or worst impulses, earn you a token. These tokens help you to weave dramatic arcs for your characters with far more control and simplicity than capricious dice, and make it easy for just about anyone to jump in and start playing.
 There are no masters—each player controls both a character and a share of the role of game master, taking responsibility for all of the NPCs and narrative pressures within one aspect of the setting (for example, THE INTERSTELLAR WAR or THE SCUM & VILLAINY). It's more like you're all taking turns playing the antagonists & introducing complications, rather than playing a game entirely without a GM.
Also drawing from Dream Askew, ORBITAL is a game of Belonging Outside Belonging. This means it focuses on stories on marginalised, precarious communities working to live independently from a dominant culture.
A sneak peek of some of the game's interior art, by turbo.torbo
Like many of our favourite role-playing games, ORBITAL begins with everyone sitting down to make their characters. You’ll each choose from six CHARACTER ROLES—archetypes that help you create a distinctive main character. You’ll each also choose & personalise one of six SETTING ELEMENTS—aspects of the game world that can introduce challenges and complicate your character’s lives. Filling the two sheets out is quick, fun, and will generate a messy web of story threads to start mulling over.
Finally, you'll work together to create your STATION. This place, unique to your table, will be a hopeful space that is struggling against pressures both within and without. You'll think about what it looks like, how it's structured, and choose a few things that are frequent sources of strife within the community. You'll also choose one pressing threat — a perilous event that threatens to light a spark to all the powder built up within your ragtag, turbulent space station.
As you start to explore these threats, you’ll ask questions which will lead to scenes between characters, using your various moves to shape the narrative in material, concrete directions. You’ll bargain and gossip, analyse and manage, love and celebrate, struggle and fight, and all the rest.
Ultimately, through play, you’ll decide the fate of your community and the station as equal storytellers in your own unique tale.
You can play a satisfying one-shot in 3-4 hours, or play through a series of sessions to explore your station further and further complicate your character's relationships. It can be played with up to 6 players, and also includes rules for playing with a GM and 1-4 players.
Kickstarter
So why Kickstarter?
ORBITAL is already mostly written, and I’m deep into playtesting & tweaking all the content within the book. My motivations for bringing the game to Kickstarter are mostly the same as for my previous project, Artefact; so that I can fill it with beautiful art!
A previous piece by turbo.torbo that inspired me to reach out
My collaborator on this project is the wonderful Torben Bökemeyer, better known as turbo.torbo on socials. He’s got a real knack for sci-fi art - especially spaceships - filling them with life through all these little stories unfolding across the illustrations.
A sneak peek of some of the game's interior art, by turbo.torbo

Also like Artefact, I want to fund another high-quality Risograph print run of the zine on premium papers — which has some minimum quantities required to make it viable. Several of the stretch goals from my last project - namely a larger format, metallic inks and stitched binding - will be part of the funding goal for this project. I can't imagine making the book without them!
Some RISO print samples from Artefact's production
Finally, Kickstarter offers a model for my designs that doesn’t threaten to turn a passion into a business. I started going down the road of distribution & managing inventory with Artefact, but I noticed (with some help from my family!) that it was quickly filling my precious spare time with the parts of this endeavour which aren’t much fun for me (emails, contracts, packing, logistics) and leaving no time for design. Also, the economies of Riso encourage you to go in hard on numbers, which would again turn my house into something resembling the big warehouse at the end of Raiders...
This all means I have no plans to make physical copies of ORBITAL available through general retail after this campaign. Other than the handful of spares & seconds that I end up with after the campaign, this will be your only chance to get the zine.
Rewards
For every backer of this campaign, I’ll make one digital community copy available on itch.io once the game is released. These free copies can be claimed by those who are marginalised / in need. This has been a really successful way of getting Artefact into the hands of those who otherwise wouldn't be able to play it, especially during these volatile times, and I'm keen to replicate that model for ORBITAL.
So, with that in mind, here are the rewards you can choose from: 
Digital Edition
The digital edition contains a PDF copy of ORBITAL & the sheets you’ll need to run the game, delivered through itch.io. To ensure the best reading experience, three formats of the book will be provided;
One formatted for home printing, with economical ink & paper usage in mind.
One formatted for screens, with a layout designed for phones & tablets. This version will be screen reader compatible.
One formatted for accessibility, with a design optimised for those with dyslexia / low vision / visual processing needs. This version will also be screen reader compatible.
Physical Edition
The physical edition includes everything from the Digital Edition tier, plus a printed copy of ORBITAL. The printed book will contain all the rules for the game, and an overview of each of the character & setting playbooks. You'll need to print the playkit sheets yourself if you're playing in-person — these contain the full playbooks that you can circle, write & sketch all over to create your setting.
The physical book will be produced with a similar specification to my previous project, Artefact. While the spec is subject to change based on proofs, I expect it to be:
32 pages, plus cover.
Reduced A5 size (194x135mm)
 GF Smith Colorplan paper cover stock, Imperial Blue
 Paperback Context recycled paper interior stock, Birch.
Risograph printed inks; metallic gold & white on the cover, risofederal blue & flat gold on the interior.
Singer-stitched binding, using white thread.
My goal with the print specification, as it was for Artefact, is to evoke a ’DIY’ zine feel, with uncoated stock and a print process reminiscent of screen-printing. However, unlike most homemade zines, I'm using luxurious papers and rich inks that make the thing feel like a premium object. I was really satisfied with the way the Artefact books turned out, and from the feedback it seems my backers were too. Here’s hoping we can capture that magic a second time!
Facilitated Session
In what might turn out to be the very height of hubris, I'm tentatively offering a few designer-facilitated online sessions of ORBITAL. These would be conducted over video chat with you and your friends, and over 3-4 hours we'd go through character & setting creation and then move into actual play. I'd act as the facilitator, tasked with knowing the rules inside-out (ha!) & helping the group get the most out of the game. I could also, alternatively, take the role of a more traditional GM if that's preferable.
(I can't promise we won't be interrupted by my toddler, cats, chickens etc, but otherwise I'll do my best to keep things mostly professional...)
This tier also includes everything from the Physical Edition tier, with free shipping as a little thank you for indulging me.

Shipping
I'm coordinating with both UK and US-based distributors this time around, as I've got no desire to try and ship out zines with a toddler and a newborn in the house! I talk a little in 'Risks & Challenges' about the challenges of shipping, especially within the US at the moment, but at the moment I expect the cost of shipping to be between £3 and £5 within the UK, and between $9 and $12 internationally. This is a little more than last time, because I don't feel confident sending untracked mail at this time. Hopefully it means you'll get your rewards reliably & swiftly!
A sneak peek of some of the game's interior art, by turbo.torbo
Deluxe Editions?
Unlike Artefact, I won't be offering Deluxe Editions for this project. 
I really wanted to! I had all the stationery picked out & everything. But we're expecting a second baby in just a couple of months, and I know that it's not sensible to commit to such a time-consuming, perfectionist-inducing offering when I’m gonna be trapped underneath a demanding newborn for the forseeable. 
I can’t wait to put together another boxed edition in the future, but I didn’t want to wait for things to settle (an interminable, unknowable concept for any parent!) to launch this project. 
Team
Even as a relatively small-scale project, ORBITAL is very much a group effort. Here's who's involved:
 Jack Harrison — part-time game designer, exhausted parent.
 Torben Bökemeyer — a freelance Game Artist, Graphic Designer and Game Dev Generalist from Berlin, Torben is our principal illustrator on the project. He's doing the illustrations for the cover and the interior chapter pages.
 Dizzy Ink — a print, design and creative workshop studio based in the heart of Nottingham, UK. They specialise in using stencil-based printing processes such as Risograph, mimeograph and screen printing. I worked with their team for the printing of Artefact, and have nothing but good things to say!
 Fiona Maeve Geist & Jarrett Crader — our diligent, eagle-eyed editors, here to stop me overusing commas, misusing dashes and creating monstrous run-on sentences that should really have stopped quite a long time ago.
 Yubi — Yubi is a nonbinary TTRPG creator and accessibility consultant who believes in an accessible future for all in tabletop gaming. They will be ensuring the Digital Edition is fully screen reader optimised, as well as creating a second version of designed with a variety of visual needs in mind.
I'm hopeful this team will grow even bigger if the project goes beyond its initial funding goal!
So there we have it — a fairly simple project for these very complicated times.
Thanks for reading!
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
The major risks to this project I’ve identified are the resurgence of COVID-19 within the UK (a second wave), and the deteriorating US postage situation (USPS).

The first, while horrifying, will hopefully not be anything too surprising. Provided my family avoids contracting the illness, lockdown will not be a new experience anymore. The closure of facilities (such as the printer or binding) and delays to domestic post might mean that the project suffers some delays, but it shouldn’t prevent delivery. I’ve included quite a bit of extra time in the delivery estimates to account for this.

The second is a bit more complicated, as it relies somewhat on predicting the actions of a maniacal autocrat. Royal Mail, who partner with the USPS to deliver mail within the United States, are the only cost-effective option for shipping rewards out to backers. But, as I’m sure many of you are acutely aware of, the USPS are under political attack and are experiencing significant delays processing mail. I don’t know how this situation will wash out, but the worst case scenario is that I won’t be able to use USPS. The main way I’m hoping to mitigate this risk is by working with a US fulfilment provider, rather than shipping individual zines internationally from here. This gives us a lot more flexibility in getting rewards delivered as we can choose the most appropriate services / providers when the time comes. It also, hopefully, means that shipping won’t be too expensive even if we have to go with a private company.

The other challenge worth mentioning is that we’re expecting a second baby in late October. The plan is to have all the work done before baby arrives, and most of that work is already well underway. However, things don’t always go to plan with new arrivals, so I’d ask for your patience if required. Provided all goes relatively smoothly, though, we’ll have no problems — most of my games have been written at odd times in the night, or with a napping baby strapped to my front, so this will be nothing new!

—————

This is my second project, having successfully delivered my first project - Artefact - over the first half of this year. While I had hoped to beat my estimates, I’m quite proud that despite a global pandemic I managed to deliver almost all of the rewards within my original June estimate. We suffered delays throughout the project due to closures and pressure on international shipping, but my backers were always supportive so long as I kept them informed. Regular updates & a live project tracker on Trello were essential communication tools, and I intend to repeat them this time around. I’ve also made changes (fulfilment partner, no deluxe editions) to ensure I’m not overstretched. Let’s do this!

Hey folks!
This update is dedicated to my partner, who has done far more than her fair share of childcare this month to give me time to work on ORBITAL. While I’d been making good progress, I knew I needed a big push to get the project delivered in line with my plans. 
So here we are! It’s amazing what a few nights of unbroken sleep and uninterrupted days can produce. Let me tell you all the things that have happened this month.

Hey folks,
Listen, I'm gonna be real for a moment. When I chose to pitch ORBITAL as my second Kickstarter project, the core of that decision was pragmatism. Dream Station, ORBITAL's predecessor, was a complete, playtested game but I had never been quite happy with how it was presented. So, I figured it would be nice to take it, jazz it up with a new layout & art, and release it. It would be a relatively simple project, because 2020 is a dick and because I knew we had a second child on the way.

Hey folks!
Holy hell, what a month it's been. We're just about to emerge from our second 'full lockdown' (?) here in the UK and while I'm fully in support of the measures, I am very bored of the inside of my walls at this point. Progress on the game has been slow with a bored toddler & mewling newborn in the house, but I'm steadily working through the tasks wherever I can find the time.

I just filled out my backerkit order and was a little surprised by the shipping (£8.50 on £12.00 pledge). You disclosed it in the description, but down in what I'd call the 'fine print'. Next time you might think of including a bit of shipping in the base cost (e.b. £4.00 shipping credit). That increases the printed base cost to £16.00 and would lower my shipping to £4.50, or maybe a little more to cover Kickstarter fees. That would make the shipping-to-product ratio less eye opening.

You could always increase your backing amount by the cost of the shipping, then you would have that credit included. Some of us just backed the digital though, so it makes sense to only include shipping as a post expense. Also, the cost of shipping is greatly determined by where you live, so $4 might be more than enough for one person and nothing for another. Keep in mind that shipping costs can change dramatically between the launch and the actual shipment of a kickstarter, and that often if there is a net negative change that the author ends up paying the costs to ship physical products. If a lot of people back physical and then switch to digital in the backerkit, how does the cumulative loss of that $4 shipping credit affect the overall net shipping cost for the author? There is also a bit of an ethics debate within kickstarter as well over the inclusion of shipping costs, as some people use the total kickstarted amount as a selling point to get investors and publishers down the road, and including shipping cost is a way to artificially inflate your totals without getting more backers.

Fair enough, I could have added extra for shipping if I thought it was going to be a lot -- my comment was more that it was a shock at the end. Even an estimate in the fine print would have helped. As an all-digital backer, you should not have been charged shipping at all. Simply roll them and put in the pocket.
2 special pockets keep your shoes perfectly in place with covers that prevent scuffing.

Pack up to 6 underpants and 6 pairs of socks without them getting loose.
Keep your bathing and cosmetic items separate from your clothes in the breathable and zippable compartment.

Keep all your tech items safe and organized -- cords, chargers, action cameras and anything else! Includes special lock for your keys!

Hello dear backers,
This is Elizabeth again, back with a new project. I was shocked after my initial launch of the Magellan Vacuum Bags Project here on Kickstarter that amassed over 2000 backers and raised over $70000!
I just want to tell you all again how thankful I am!
After the Kickstarter campaign was ready, I had a lot of short travels with just my backpack, and I started to wonder if there was a more effective way to travel with just a backpack – a way to easily organize everything I needed, quickly and conveniently.
After some research on what people often take with them during small flights, I started to experiment with different forms of the backpack that would allow me to pack everything fast enough and organize properly. I wanted to go further than just Vacuum Bags - I wanted to give a solution that would use the backpack space to its’ maximum.
